MID-YEAR COTILLON
ON JANUARY 31
Following the examinations,
on the night of the 31st of
January, the Cotillon Club will
give the mid-year Cotillon at
the Southern Hotel. Music
will begin at 9.30 and last until
2, while the cost of admission
will be $3 a couple and $2
stag.

Up Reserves

Dr. Vernon Cook to
Address Assembly

GENERAL GAITHER
ADDRESSES ASSEMBLY
Police Commissioner Speaks at
Weekly Assembly
STRESSES CIVIC DUTY
Three-fifths of Force Employed
In Auto Regulation
"Everyone should realize the
value of the police department,"
said Police Commissioner Gaither
at last week's assembly.
In relating the value and various
functions of this branch of our
municipal government, Commissioner Gaither said, "The three primary purposes of the Baltimore Police department are, the suppression
of crime, the apprehension of criminals and the protection of life and
property." With these three objects as a basis, General Gaither developed his talk in sequential and
effective succession.
The Assembly was told that the
police department consists of a personnel numbering fifteen hundred
men. This, including the ranks of
patrolmen, detectives, sergeants,
lieutenants and other officials, costs
the public or, in softer words, extracts from the public exchequer
the sum total of four millions of
dollars, or about one-tenth of the
year's budget. This knoWledge was
softened by the stressed fact of the
absolute necessity of the police
force in our community.
While stressing this the commissioner of police said, "Not only
must the police suppress actual
crime, but their duties are of the
most varied sort. For example, it
takes two hundred and sixty-five
men a day to protect school children. This means that a patrolman
works from ten to twelve hours a
day instead of the prescribed eight.
"However, the big problem that
we have to meet is caused by our
motor vehicles. Last year, alone.
there were fifty-six thousand arrests
made for violation of automobile
regulations. This required the time

BARNSTORMERS CLUB
STOPS REHEARSALS
Announcement was made
Friday by H. Ridgely Warfield, Jr., acting president of
the Barnstormers' Club, that
all rehearsals of the cast had
been discontinued until after
examinations.
The inability of Walter B.
Swindell, Jr., the coach of the
Barnstormers, to be present at
these rehearsals, and the fact
that a definite play has not
been selected, combined with
the proximity of examinations,
has caused this action.

AN OLD BUGABOO
One of the leading manifestations of the continuance of the
so-called "prep school point of view" in the undergraduate school
is the increasing importance being placed upon marks by both
the students and some of the members of the faculty. Every
time a quiz or even an oral recitation is given, the members of
the class want to know "what mark they got." If a semi-official
questioning of the class takes place, the class immediately wants
to know whether it "counts" or not.
It is the most natural thing in the world for a man to want to
know how he is progressing in whatever line of endeavor occupies his interests. In the case of so many students, however,
there seems to be a desire not only for a knowledge of the progress he is making, but for an expression of that knowledge from
time to time in some numerical form.
There are a few isolated cases where, it is conceivable, the announcement of marks at regular intervals might be of positive
good to the student. Such cases would be courses such as composition courses, where the student is not in a position to judge
the caliber of his own work. The very great majority of students, however, know whether their work is good, bad or indifferent without having to compute for themselves an average of half
a dozen 6's, 8's and 7.5's.
Many of the instructors, particularly the student assistants,
are as much to blame as the students themselves. The emphasis
of the importance of weekly or semi-monthly quizzes has the
unfailing tendency to make the mark not an expression of the
student's progress in the course, but the end itself of the course.
The "evils" of stressing marks have been enumerated too often
to warrant repetition. The solution to the growing tendency
would be either not to make public marks received for work done
during the semester, or else, if ,the instructor feels that the curiosity of his students deserves satisfaction, return all papers at the
end of the semester.

EXTIRPATING THE COLD
Usually when a wealthy man or big foundation gives a large
sum of money for investigation into the causes of a disease; he
picks a death-dealing plague that has long ravished humankind.
Not so with the Chemical Foundation, however. Believing that
in chemistry lie the cures of many.diseases, the Chemical Foundation has appropriated $195,000. to be used at the Johns Hopkins
Medical School by Dr. John J. Abel, for research into the causes
and remedies for the poor, old, common cold!
Dr. Abel is given five years in which to use the allotted sum.
By the end of that time, it is hoped, his efforts may bear fruit.
If he succeeds in discovering a cure for that least harmful but
most annoying ailment, who knows but that his popularity will
equal that of Lindbergh! Patent medicine manufacturers have
tried for years and years to cure the cold; now Science is about
to make the attempt. Is it too much to hope that she will be
wholly successful?

A PLEA FOR "PEP."
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir: I notice in your list of
requirements for an article in this
part of your paper that you invite
the freest of discussions on subjects
of interest to the "inmates" of our
co-operative plan, or rather, their
co-operative plan.
When our basketball team was
in its early stages of development
there was much discussion about the
necessity of support of the team,
etc. Our team opened the season
by handing a defeat to the five representing Loyola College. Newspaper criticism, as is usually the case
in Baltimore, was criticism of destructive character, until our team
displayed the brand of basketball
that forced them to admit that our
team was a good one.
Now that our team has proved
itself, let us as the potential backers, perform in a way in which each
one, as students, are bound. Support this team by our attendance
and by our interest. Remember,
we can beat Maryland in basketball,
W. H. D.
too.

FOR SHAME!
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir: Probably 90 per cent.
of the students at Hopkins are
mentally kicking themselves for
having utilized more or less valuable time to view the dingus holding
forth at the Maryland last week.
Why do so many Hopkins men attend such maudlin demonstrations
of human depravity? While the
characteristic audience is composed
mostly of young girls, one can very
easily espy numbers of the Hopkins
intelligensia here and there.
Why? Naturally, Finklestein's
star saleslady is there; she must
have a thrill some time in her young
life. But why Hopkins?
H. F. M., JR.

Series of Readings
Professor Ernst Feise, of the
German Department, last night began a second series of dramatic
readings in German by rendering
Schnitzler's "Lebendige Stunden"
and Hofmannsthel's "Der Tor lind
Der Tor."
Dr. Feise will resume his readings on the last TueSday of the
month and from that date will continue to give readings on the second
and last Monday of each month,
until March 26. On this date,
Beer-Hoffman's "Der Graf Von
Charolais" will be the drama considered.
The readings will be given in
Room 9, Gilman Hall, at 8 P. M.
The public is invited and no cards
Will be required for admission.

Gentlemen:
Most all well-known tobaccos
smoke well in a cold or temperate
climate, but very few in a tropical
climate. They are mostly too heavy,
don't seem to be blended right—at
least that is my opinion gained from
practical experience.
However, Edgeworth is the same
In any climate. Again this is my
opinion gained by practical experience.
I canot get the same pleasure out
of any brand of tobacco that I can
out of Edgeworth, and I have tried
many—and paid fancy prices, too.
It costs real money to smoke imported tobaccos here; the import
duty is very high.
Anyway, we cannot have everything we would like in these countries,•so we hold on to all the little
pleasures possible. Now you know
why I smoke Edgeworth.
Yours respectfully,
It. C. Rigg,
Cartagena, Columbia, S. A.

In making telephones as in debating, one achievement serves only to stimulate the effort toward fresh
successes and to overcome new problems as they arise.
In manufacturing communication equipment at
Western Electric a wide range of problems is constantly being faced and conquered — in the laboratories where small switchboard lamp manufacturing
is planned; in the punch press rooms where huge
presses pound away; in the production department
where forward planning controls the flow of work.
As the college debater applies himself to preparing
new and better arguments, so Western Electric men
unceasingly apply themselves to devising new and
better methods in the production and distribution of
the nation's telephone equipment needs.

JAY COURT FIVE TO MEET OLD LINE
QUINT TONIGHT AT CARLIN'S PARK
Tonight's game will probably be
the hardest the Jays have encountered on their schedule so far this
year. Any athletic contest with
Maryland is bound to be a fight
from start to finish, almost regardless of the respective merits of the
teams. The Old-Liners will be out
to avenge the defeats in lacrosse
and football they have suffered at
the hands of the Black and Blue
team.
Maryland Very Strong
That Maryland has a strong team
is evidenced by the fact that they
won four Southern Conference
games in a row, defeating V. P. I.,
V. M. I., and Washington and Lee,
the latter team meeting two reverses
at the hands of the Ravens. This
week they have had an intensive
schedule, meeting Gallaudet, Kentucky University and Hopkins on
successive nights.
The team which meets Hopkins
tonight is an exceptionally strong
one. Radice, a sophomore, will be
watched with especial care. Last
year he was the ace of the freshman team and this year, so far, he
is high point scorer. Fred Linkous,
who, incidentally, is captain of the
Terrapins, has not been starting the
games this year, but has been kept
on the bench as reserve, along with
Madigan, Zahn and Hedzel, who
usually break into the line-up some
time during every game. Adams
and Heagy are the two regulars of
last year's team who will start
against the Jay quint. . It is probA. H. FETTING

GENERAL GAITHER
ADDRESSES ASSEMBLY
Police Commissioner Speaks at
Weekly Assembly
STRESSES CIVIC DUTY
Three-fifths of Force Employed
In Auto Regulation
"Everyone should realize the
value of the police department,"
said Police Commissioner Gaither
at last week's assembly.
In relating the value and various
functions of this branch of our
municipal government, Commissioner Gaither said, "The three primary purposes of the Baltimore Police department are, the suppression
of crime, the apprehension of criminals and the protection of life and
property." With these three objects as a basis, General Gaither developed his talk in sequential and
effective succession.
The Assembly was told that the
police department consists of a personnel numbering fifteen hundred
men. This, including the ranks of
patrolmen, detectives, sergeants,
lieutenants and other officials, costs
the public or, in softer words, extracts from the public exchequer
the sum total of four millions of
dollars, or about one-tenth of the
year's budget. This knoWledge was
softened by the stressed fact of the
absolute necessity of the police
force in our community.
While stressing this the commissioner of police said, "Not only
must the police suppress actual
crime, but their duties are of the
most varied sort. For example, it
takes two hundred and sixty-five
men a day to protect school children. This means that a patrolman
works from ten to twelve hours a
day instead of the prescribed eight.
"However, the big problem that
we have to meet is caused by our
motor vehicles. Last year, alone.
there were fifty-six thousand arrests
made for violation of automobile
regulations. This required the time

been selected, combined with
the proximity of examinations,
has caused this action.

AN OLD BUGABOO
One of the leading manifestations of the continuance of the
so-called "prep school point of view" in the undergraduate school
is the increasing importance being placed upon marks by both
the students and some of the members of the faculty. Every
time a quiz or even an oral recitation is given, the members of
the class want to know "what mark they got." If a semi-official
questioning of the class takes place, the class immediately wants
to know whether it "counts" or not.
It is the most natural thing in the world for a man to want to
know how he is progressing in whatever line of endeavor occupies his interests. In the case of so many students, however,
there seems to be a desire not only for a knowledge of the progress he is making, but for an expression of that knowledge from
time to time in some numerical form.
There are a few isolated cases where, it is conceivable, the announcement of marks at regular intervals might be of positive
good to the student. Such cases would be courses such as composition courses, where the student is not in a position to judge
the caliber of his own work. The very great majority of students, however, know whether their work is good, bad or indifferent without having to compute for themselves an average of half
a dozen 6's, 8's and 7.5's.
Many of the instructors, particularly the student assistants,
are as much to blame as the students themselves. The emphasis
of the importance of weekly or semi-monthly quizzes has the
unfailing tendency to make the mark not an expression of the
student's progress in the course, but the end itself of the course.
The "evils" of stressing marks have been enumerated too often
to warrant repetition. The solution to the growing tendency
would be either not to make public marks received for work done
during the semester, or else, if ,the instructor feels that the curiosity of his students deserves satisfaction, return all papers at the
end of the semester.

EXTIRPATING THE COLD
Usually when a wealthy man or big foundation gives a large
sum of money for investigation into the causes of a disease; he
picks a death-dealing plague that has long ravished humankind.
Not so with the Chemical Foundation, however. Believing that
in chemistry lie the cures of many.diseases, the Chemical Foundation has appropriated $195,000. to be used at the Johns Hopkins
Medical School by Dr. John J. Abel, for research into the causes
and remedies for the poor, old, common cold!
Dr. Abel is given five years in which to use the allotted sum.
By the end of that time, it is hoped, his efforts may bear fruit.
If he succeeds in discovering a cure for that least harmful but
most annoying ailment, who knows but that his popularity will
equal that of Lindbergh! Patent medicine manufacturers have
tried for years and years to cure the cold; now Science is about
to make the attempt. Is it too much to hope that she will be
wholly successful?

A PLEA FOR "PEP."
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir: I notice in your list of
requirements for an article in this
part of your paper that you invite
the freest of discussions on subjects
of interest to the "inmates" of our
co-operative plan, or rather, their
co-operative plan.
When our basketball team was
in its early stages of development
there was much discussion about the
necessity of support of the team,
etc. Our team opened the season
by handing a defeat to the five representing Loyola College. Newspaper criticism, as is usually the case
in Baltimore, was criticism of destructive character, until our team
displayed the brand of basketball
that forced them to admit that our
team was a good one.
Now that our team has proved
itself, let us as the potential backers, perform in a way in which each
one, as students, are bound. Support this team by our attendance
and by our interest. Remember,
we can beat Maryland in basketball,
W. H. D.

FOR SHAME!
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir: Probably 90 per cent.
of the students at Hopkins are
mentally kicking themselves for
having utilized more or less valuable time to view the dingus holding
forth at the Maryland last week.
Why do so many Hopkins men attend such maudlin demonstrations
of human depravity? While the
characteristic audience is composed
mostly of young girls, one can very
easily espy numbers of the Hopkins
intelligensia here and there.
Why? Naturally, Finklestein's
star saleslady is there; she must
have a thrill some time in her young
life. But why Hopkins?
H. F. M., JR.

Professor Ernst Feise, of the
German Department, last night began a second series of dramatic
readings in German by rendering
Schnitzler's "Lebendige Stunden"
and Hofmannsthel's "Der Tor lind
Der Tor."
Dr. Feise will resume his readings on the last TueSday of the
month and from that date will continue to give readings on the second
and last Monday of each month,
until March 26. On this date,
Beer-Hoffman's "Der Graf Von
Charolais" will be the drama considered.
The readings will be given in
Room 9, Gilman Hall, at 8 P. M.
The public is invited and no cards
Will be required for admission.

Gentlemen:
Most all well-known tobaccos
smoke well in a cold or temperate
climate, but very few in a tropical
climate. They are mostly too heavy,
don't seem to be blended right—at
least that is my opinion gained from
practical experience.
However, Edgeworth is the same
In any climate. Again this is my
opinion gained by practical experience.
I canot get the same pleasure out
of any brand of tobacco that I can
out of Edgeworth, and I have tried
many—and paid fancy prices, too.
It costs real money to smoke imported tobaccos here; the import
duty is very high.
Anyway, we cannot have everything we would like in these countries,•so we hold on to all the little
pleasures possible. Now you know
why I smoke Edgeworth.
Yours respectfully,
It. C. Rigg,
Cartagena, Columbia, S. A.

where forward planning controls the flow of work.

better methods in the production and distribution of

JAY COURT FIVE TO MEET OLD LINE
QUINT TONIGHT AT CARLIN'S PARK
Tonight's game will probably be
the hardest the Jays have encountered on their schedule so far this
year. Any athletic contest with
Maryland is bound to be a fight
from start to finish, almost regardless of the respective merits of the
teams. The Old-Liners will be out
to avenge the defeats in lacrosse
and football they have suffered at
the hands of the Black and Blue
team.
Maryland Very Strong
That Maryland has a strong team
is evidenced by the fact that they
won four Southern Conference
games in a row, defeating V. P. I.,
V. M. I., and Washington and Lee,
the latter team meeting two reverses
at the hands of the Ravens. This
week they have had an intensive
schedule, meeting Gallaudet, Kentucky University and Hopkins on
successive nights.
The team which meets Hopkins
tonight is an exceptionally strong
one. Radice, a sophomore, will be
watched with especial care. Last
year he was the ace of the freshman team and this year, so far, he
is high point scorer. Fred Linkous,
who, incidentally, is captain of the
Terrapins, has not been starting the
games this year, but has been kept
on the bench as reserve, along with
Madigan, Zahn and Hedzel, who
usually break into the line-up some
time during every game. Adams
and Heagy are the two regulars of
last year's team who will start
against the Jay quint. . It is probA. H. FETTING
